questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Exchange Online tenant.

You need to display a list of Exchange PowerShell management role entries that relate to the Reset Password role.

Which cmdlet should you run?

Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
Your company has a Microsoft Exchange Server 2019 hybrid deployment that contains two Mailbox servers named MBX1 and MBX2.
The company has the departments shown in the following table.
//IMG//

From the on-premises organization, outbound email is sent directly to the Internet by using DNS lookups.
You are informed that some sales department users send email messages that are identified as spam.
You need to automatically block the sales department users from repeatedly sending spam.
Solution: You modify the outbound spam filter policy in Exchange Online.
Does this meet the goal?
questions.answer_description: From the on-premises organization, outbound email is sent directly to the Internet by using DNS lookups. Therefore, the Exchange Online outbound spam filter will not scan the emails sent from the on-premises mailboxes.

discussion.content: Correct. SCL value of 7 and above will be rejected. Quarantine and Delete isn't enabled.
Correct , but so weird the reject thershold set lower than quantine

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You are evaluating the email hygiene configuration of a Microsoft Exchange Server 2019 organization.
You run the command shown in the following exhibit.
//IMG//

Use the drop-down menus to select the answer choice that completes each statement based on the information presented in the graphic.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

HOTSPOT -
You have a Microsoft Exchange Online tenant.
You plan to filter all inbound and outbound email messages by using a third-party message hygiene solution.
You need to ensure that all the email sent and received by the tenant is filtered through the message hygiene solution. The solution must ensure that only the message hygiene solution can send email to the tenant.
What should you configure for the tenant? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content: Answer Correct, MX e Inbound/Outbound connector.

comments.content:
Not really...
Correct0 is MX and Inbound and outbound connectors.

Requirements:
You need to ensure that all the email sent and received by the tenant is filtered through the message hygiene solution.

So if you want EXTENAL mail servers send all e-mail to your 3rd party solution you specify your mail receiving solution in MX record.
For the traffic INBOUND and OUTBOUND you create two connectors.

Additionally:
Autodiscover CNAME DNS record participate only in automatic configuration for Outlook client to fetch (i. e. to know your Exchange Server SMTP address). This record participate in sending e-mail by defining your Exchange server (where it send e-mails) because Outlook itself doesn't send E-mails directly anywhere else (works strictly CLIENT-SERVER, not SERVER architecture) beside the server (EXCHANGE).

discussion.content:
I would say:
Alias (CNAME) - for Autodiscover
Inbound and outbound connector for mail flow to and from MHS
MX should not be configured for the tenant because it should point to the MHS.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have an Exchange Online tenant that has the anti-spam settings configured as shown in the following exhibit.
//IMG//

Use the drop-down menus to select the answer choice that completes each statement based on the information presented in the graphic.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
When you create an anti-spam policy.
Then see description: "A higher bulk email threshold means more bulk emails are delivered."

BCL Description

0 The message isn't from a bulk sender.

1, 2, 3 The message is from a bulk sender that generates few complaints.

4, 5, 6, 7* The message is from a bulk sender that generates a mixed number of complaints.

8, 9 The message is from a bulk sender that generates a high number of complaints.

comments.content: sorry... read it wrong..... decrease is correct.
safety tips will show up on all versions of outlook which are supported by exchange online
First answer is "Outlook on the web" as "Microsoft 2019" is not a part of Office 365 it's a standalone version.

discussion.content:
for me: 
- First Answer is correct (All versions of Outlook supported by Office 365 can display MailTips, so no change is required to support the red safety tip.)
- Second Answer should be "increase the vaule of Bulk threshold" (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-gb/microsoft-365/security/office-365-security/bulk-complaint-level-values?view=o365-worldwide)
> 0 The message isn't from a bulk sender.
> 8, 9 The message is from a bulk sender that generates a high number of complaints.
1 marks the most bulk email as spam and 9 allows the most bulk email to be delivered.
